projects.tavl

Class ThreadedAVLTree<T extends java.lang.Comparable<T>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • projects.tavl.ThreadedAVLTree<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - The Comparable type held by the data structure.

    public class ThreadedAVLTree<T extends java.lang.Comparable<T>>
extends java.lang.Object

    ThreadedAVLTree implements threaded Adelson-Velsky-Landis (AVL) trees (shorthand: TAVL trees). These trees:

    1. Allow for efficient lookup, insertion and deletion in O(logn) time, by virtue of being AVL trees.
    2. Perform a full inorder traversal in O(n) time, by virtue of being threaded trees.

    Hence, two powerful ideas that we have talked about in lecture will now be combined in one data structure.

    To get more than 50% credit for this project, you must attempt to implement your tree as a threaded tree, as discussed in lecture. We have access to your source code after submission and we will be checking to make sure that you have been appropriately updating the tree's threads every time you must! You are also required to implement a method for generating the inorder traversal over such a tree, and this method needs to be functioning entirely stacklessly!Read the project description for more in-depth information.

    Finally, for this project, we assume that there are no duplicate keys in your data structure. This means that, in our unit tests, whenever we remove a key from your tree, we expect it to no longer be found in the tree. You may deal with this invariant in any way you please, e.g. throw an exception if a duplicate is inserted, or remove all instances of a key when we ask for a deletion.

    Author:
    ------- PUT YOUR NAME HERE! ------

    • Method Detail

      • insert

        public void insert(T key)
        Insert key in the tree.
        Parameters:
        key - The key to insert in the tree.

      • delete

        public T delete(T key)
        Delete the key from the data structure and return it to the caller. Note that it is assumed that there are no duplicate keys in the tree. That is, if a key is deleted from the tree, it should no longer be found in it.
        Parameters:
        key - The key to deleteRec from the structure.
        Returns:
        The key that was removed, or null if the key was not found.

      • search

        public T search(T key)
        Search for key in the tree. Return a reference to it if it's in there, or null otherwise.
        Parameters:
        key - The key to look for in the tree.
        Returns:
        key if key is in the tree, or null otherwise.

      • height

        public int height()
        Return the height of the tree. The height of the tree is defined as the length of the longest path between the root and the leaf level. By definition of path length, a stub tree has a height of 0, and we define an empty tree to have a height of -1.
        Returns:
        The height of the tree.

      • isEmpty

        public boolean isEmpty()
        Query the tree for emptiness. A tree is empty iff it has zero keys stored.
        Returns:
        true if the tree is empty, false otherwise.

      • getRoot

        public T getRoot()
        Return the key at the tree's root node.
        Returns:
        The key at the tree's root node, or null if the tree is empty.

      • inorderTraversal

        public java.util.Iterator<T> inorderTraversal()
        Generate an inorder traversal over the tree's stored keys. This should be done by using the tree's threads, to be able to find every inorder successor in amortized constant time. TO GET MORE THAN 50% CREDIT IN THIS PROJECT, YOU MUST IMPLEMENT YOUR TREE AS A THREADED TREE. IN PARTICULAR, TO GET ANY CREDIT FOR THIS METHOD, YOUR CODE MUST PASS THE RELEVANT UNIT TESTS AND YOU MUST BE MAKING NO CALLS TO ANY STACK, YOURS OR THE SYSTEM'S!
        Returns:
        An Iterator over Ts, which exposes the elements in ascending order. If the tree is empty, the Iterator's first call to Iterator.hasNext() will return false. The behavior of Iterator.remove() is undefined; we do not test for removal of elements through the returned Iterator, so you can implement Iterator.remove() in any way you please.
